model_details.name: Discussing the Value of Automatic Hate Speech Detection in Online Debates
model_details.overview: In this experiment logistic Regression is tested on a self created german dataset.
model_details.documentation:
This study discusses the potential value of automatic analytics of
German texts to detect hate speech. In the course of a preliminary study, we
collected a dataset of user comments on news articles, focused on the refugee
crisis in 2015/16. A crowdsourcing approach was used to label a subset of the
data as hateful and non-hateful to be used as training and evaluation data.
Furthermore, a vocabulary was created containing the words that are indicating
hate and no hate. The best performing combination of feature groups was a
Word2Vec approach and Extended 2-grams. Our study builds upon previous
research for English texts and demonstrates its transferability to German. The
paper discusses the results with respect to the potential for media organizations
and considerations about moderation techniques and algorithmic transparency

data.name: German Dataset
data.description: Dataset obtained from german newspaper sites. Available Data show all annotated data, while the test Data show the annotated Data after undersampling.

graphics.description: Metrics achieved by using different features sets

tradeoffs.description: Relatively small size of the dataset
Focus on the topic of the refugee crisis
Potential pre-filtered dataset because of possible moderation work on scraped platforms

ethical_considerations.name:
Because of the used scraping technique, there may have been errors when scraping comments.
                Further many platforms had to be discarded because of incompatibility with the scarping method
ethical_considerations.mitigation_strategy: Larger international newspapers (e.g. New York Times) offer API, encourage German news platforms to do the same
